p: The association of the zero/low carbon development agenda, which is proposed as a solution for the planetary future, with old practices of exporting the international political economy’s asymmetries from developed to developing nations (North–South and South-South), calls into question the legitimacy of the constitutive norms of the climate agenda itself. As Björkdahl (2002) recall, ‘norms are concerned with the desirability of means and goals themselves’, which indicates that prescriptions that emphasize notions like responsibility, just transition and resilience through moral or ethical norms of behaviour must be analyzed more critically upon empirical scenarios of standard violations. From the analysis of the EU-Brazil and China-Brazil practices in this article, the harmonization of common interests presents great challenges for future climate norms and standards.
